name: textgreper
prompt: write a python script that will emulate the function of grep and sed in the commandline. The user will call the script along with the file that needs to be processed.

classified_tasks.task: 1. As a user, I want to be able to run the script from the command line.
2. As a user, I want to provide the filename as an argument when running the script.
3. As a user, I want to be able to search for a specific word in the file content.
4. As a user, I want to be able to display lines containing the searched word.
5. As a user, I want to be able to count the number of occurrences of the searched word in the file.
6. As a user, I want to be able to replace a specific word with another word in the file content.
7. As a user, I want to be able to save the modified content back to the original file or a new file.
8. As a user, I want to be able to use regular expressions for searching and replacing.
9. As a user, I want to be able to specify options like case-insensitive search.
10. As a user, I want to see help information on how to use the script.
11. As a user, I want to see version information of the script.
12. As a user, I want to be able to search for multiple words simultaneously.
13. As a user, I want to be able to display line numbers along with the matching lines.
14. As a user, I want to be able to preview the changes before saving them.
15. As a user, I want to be able to undo the last change made using the script.
16. As a user, I want to be able to perform in-place editing of the file without creating a new file.
17. As a user, I want to be able to specify the output format (e.g., plain text, JSON).
18. As a user, I want to be able to search for words that start or end with a specific pattern.
19. As a user, I want to be able to search for whole words only.
20. As a user, I want to be able to search for lines that do not contain a specific word.
These user stories cover various functionalities and options that users might expect from the "textgreper" commandline text processor script.
